question: When did the English civil war begin?
tip: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642. The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

question: Members of the armed forces cannot stand for public office.
tip: Most citizens of the UK, the Irish Republic and the Commonwealth can stand for public office. There are some exceptions, including members of the armed forces.

question: On election day, you will get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in front of the polling officer
tip: When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name and address. In Northern Ireland you will also have to show photographic identification. You will then get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in privately

question: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities
tip: Many schools organise events to raise money for extra equipment or out-of-school activities. Activities might include book sales, toy sales or bringing food to sell.

question: The public can listen to debates in the Palace of Westminster from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords
options: No, You can only listen on the TV/radio

question: The United Nations (UN) is an international organisation with more than ______ countries as members
The Falkland Islands are a British overseas territory and are part of the United Kingdom.
Which clan was killed because of not taking an oath?
tip: All Scottish clans were required formally to accept William as king by taking an oath. The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.

question: By joining a political party, what TWO activities might you be involved in?
options: Violent clashes with other political parties
Joining your MP for sessions in the House of Commons
Handing out leaflets in the street
Knocking on people's doors and asking for support
tip: Political parties welcome new members. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates, for example, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support (this is called 'canvassing').

question: What was the estimated population of the British Empire?
tip: During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of more than 400 million people.

question: Which of these government bodies were not established in 1999?
tip: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly and a Scottish Parliament since 1999.

question: The ability to laugh at other people is an important part of the UK character
tip: The ability to laugh at ourselves is an important part of the UK character

question: Under which king did the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England unite and defeat the Vikings.
tip: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

question: Who were the first people to live in Britain in what we call the Stone Age?
Which of these countries was NOT UK's ally in the WWII?
tip: The war was initially fought between the Axis powers (fascist Germany and Italy and the Empire of Japan) and the Allies

question: Who is the fastest person to sail around the world singlehanded?
In England, Wales and Scotland, Magistrates and Justices of the Peace (JPs) usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications
Pakistan is part of the Commonwealth
tip: Pakistan is currently part of the Commonwealth

question: St Andrew's Day is on the ______
In the different parts of the UK there are many variations in language
tip: Gaelic is spoken in some parts of Scotland, in Wales many people speak Welsh, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic

question: The Speaker is an MP, he/she represents a constituency and deals with constituents’ problems like any other MP
tip: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, even though he or she is an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents’ problems like any other MP.

question: Who died at the Battle of Trafalgar?
Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes valid everywhere in the UK
tip: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

question: The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1890s by Sir Robert Watson-Watt
tip: The jet engine was developed in Britain in the 1930s by Sir Frank Whittle (1907–96), a British Royal Air Force engineer Officer.

question: There are ______ national parks in England, Wales and Scotland
Which flower is associated with England?
tip: A rose is the flower associated with England.

question: On April Fool's day people normally give each other presents
Members of the House of Lords may stand for election to the House of Commons
James Watt was famous for his work on what?
tip: James Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

question: Which TWO principles are included in the European Convention on Human Rights?
tip: Some of the principles included in the European Convention on Human Rights are: right to life; prohibition of torture; prohibition of slavery and forced labour; right to liberty and security; right to a fair trial; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; freedom of expression (speech).

question: What is the minimum age for going into betting shops or gambling clubs?
tip: You have to be 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

question: £10 £20 £50 £100 are the only banknotes currently allowed in the UK
tip: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound. The denominations (values) of currency are - coins: 1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1 and £2; notes: £5, £10, £20, £50.

question: The symbol of the House of Tudor was
options: a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies

question: Who is the head of the state?
The population in the UK in 2010 was
Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt
tip: Radar was developed by Scotsman Sir Robert Watson-Watt (1892–1973), who proposed that enemy aircraft could be detected by radio waves. The first successful radar test took place in 1935.

question: How often are members of Parliament (MPs) elected?
tip: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

question: You have to be at least 21 years old to serve on a jury.
Who is known as William the Conqueror?
tip: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

question: Which of the following discoveries contributed to the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
tip: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today. David Hume’s ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers. Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt’s work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

question: Which country’s national flower is a thistle?
tip: A thistle is a national flower of Scotland.

question: Who is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth?
tip: The Queen is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth.

question: What are the parliaments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland also known as?
tip: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. These powers are also known as devolved administrations.

question: What task is associated with the National Trust?
tip: The National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and the National Trust for Scotland, work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside.

question: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to appoint ______ just for their own lifetime
What is the name of the charity that works to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK?
tip: Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the UK. The National Trust was founded in 1895 by three volunteers. There are now more than 61,000 volunteers helping to keep the organisation running.

question: What is the day when jokes are published in newspapers and telecasted on TV?
In 1603, when Elizabeth I died her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland who became King James I of
What do Sir William Golding, Seamus Heaney and Harold Pinter have in common?
options: They are all famous British athletes.
They have all been Prime Minister.
They were part of the first British expedition to the North Pole.
They have all been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
tip: Sir William Golding, Seamus Heaney and Harold Pinter have all won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

question: When did Britain become separated from the continent?
tip: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.
